Switching Voltage regulators can show broadband noise in the LTE low band, adding ferrite bead can help in reducing the noise. Ferrite bead selection is based on the current rating of the voltage regulator input pin.ILHB1206ER121V (up to 6A); BLM31SN500SH1 (up to 12 A)

Components for Type-C Interface

The image below indicates various components added on the Type C connector for ESD, EMI and EOS protection. For more details about component selection refer “Other Component Selection (#1 to #7)” table.

Components For Type C Interface

Ferrite Bead for Power and Ground Pins of AC Jack

To prevent EMI noise passing through adapter cable adding ferrite bead at the connector pin can help. For more details refer to AC Jack (#8) details from “Other Component Selection” table.

Ferrite Beads for AC Jack

System Efficient ESD Design (SEED)

PDG Chapter “ESD Diode Selection” serves as a general recommendation for system level ESD protection. To further optimize selection of ESD diode, customers may consider using SEED simulation concept during system design phase. SEED defines an ESD robustness design concept that assures matching between PCB protection components and IC IO behavior during system ESD discharges event. It allows selection of ESD diode which is optimized based on IO characteristics and PCB design. It also promotes early assessment using a simulation to achieve first-time-right PCB design. This design concept applies to hot plug input/output port applications, that includes USB2, USB3, Type-C, DisplayPort, and HDMI.

SEED Block Diagram

SEED simulation deck is available in Advanced Design System (ADS) and HSPICE. Refer to Intel System Efficient ESD Design (SEED) User Guide (#702999) for step-by-step simulation guidance. Customers may contact the Intel representative for platform specific SEED Models.

Intel® SEED Analysis Template

EMC Audio

Audio ESD Protection

Audio jack needs to have ESD protection. The ESD diodes need to connect to digital / chassis ground.

Audio Jack ESD Protection

DMIC EMI/ RFI Risk

DMIC clock may have EMI/ RFI risk due to its high-order harmonics.

It is recommended to have stripline routing and a placeholder for an RC filter before being routed in microstrip/ cable to reduce high-frequency harmonics.

The RC value may vary according to the board design to meet the electrical requirements.

Routing Requirements and RC Filter for DMIC Clock

Wi-Fi/WWAN Radios Performance vs. Platform Noise

Noise from multiple aggressors, such as switching power supplies, high-speed digital clocks or data can generate harmonics or broadband noise that interferes with the radio bands on the platform. Noise could couple to the platform antenna hence reducing the radios performance like throughput, latency, and sensitivity by reducing the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR).

This section provides the RF platform noise threshold that can set the baseline for determining if the noise level in the radio bands is tolerable to maintain wireless performance, therefore ensuring the best user experience. To meet the noise requirement, customers could implement the mitigation solutions illustrated in the EMC General Considerations guidelines.

Platform Noise Threshold Recommendation

Each type of noise source has its own characteristic noise profile therefore has its own frequency spectrum that could have a different impact on radio performance. Scrambled data signals for high-speed interfaces (e.g. USB 3.0, DDR5, PCIE) are broadband, covering a wide frequency range and radio band in the GHz range. On the other hand, clock signals are highly periodic and have a relatively narrowband spectrum, which leads to the generation of harmonics. Unlike scrambled data, these harmonics are periodic and predictable.

Noise ProfileWi-Fi In-band Noise Threshold (dBm/100 kHz)WWAN In-band Noise Threshold (dBm/100 kHz)
Narrowband noise (<= 600 kHz Bandwidth)-106-98
Broadband Noise-117-117

The table above shows the recommended noise threshold based on experimental results. By artificially changing the noise profile and level, the figures below represent the throughput and sensitivity impact on Wi-Fi and WWAN. The noise threshold is defined according to the noise level that can ensure radio performance.

Wi-Fi Throughput Degradation by RF Noise Level
WWAN Sensitivity Degradation by RF Noise Level

On-Board Shielding

Platform on-board shielding can be an effective mitigation option against RF interference with Wi-Fi/WWAN/5G antennas. It can help to reduce the platform noise radiation and reduce susceptibility to external RF noise, particularly the memory and SSD.

General On-Board Shielding Consideration

Shielding Ground Contact

To ensure good shielding effectiveness and minimum noise leakage it is critical to have proper electrical contact of the PCB ground layer with the shielding mechanical enclosure, ideally leaving no electrical openings. Poor grounding contact or gaps/seams in the shield can reduce the shielding effectiveness. Also, the size of any aperture and opening in a mechanical shield enclosure needs to be minimized, keeping it smaller than 2.5 mm. A conductive gasket can also be used to ground the shield to the PCB.

The following figure shows a general recommendation for spacing between grounding vias (S). The general recommendation is to use via spacing ≤ λ/6 (e.g., approximately 4 mm for 7.5 GHz). To improve shielding effectiveness, use closer spacing.

On-Board Shield Grounding General Guideline

Thermal and EMI Co-Design Considerations

An integrated thermal and EMI shield co-design solution can be implemented in a system. The thermal/EMI shield solution needs to have proper electrical contact to the PCB ground layer to guarantee adequate shielding effectiveness.

An example of an EMI shield with co-optimized EMC-thermal solution consists of a large metal frame interposer that covers GPU, GDDR devices, GPU voltage regulator, CPU, DDR devices and voltage regulator. The metal frame has an electrically conductive interface and connects to the on-board GND pad opening.

Example Implementation of EMC-Thermal Solution
Metal Frame Interposer with Electrically Conductive Interface to Board

EMC Mechanical Considerations

Mechanical design of the system plays a critical role in meeting requirements for EMI, ESD, RFI, RF Immunity and EFT. The broad categories of consideration in mechanical design are chassis design, connector selection and grounding, high speed cable design and grounding.

  • All faces of the chassis should have a conductive EMI coating (in cases where metallic chassis is not used) to provide RF shielding. The sidewalls of the chassis should also have a continuous EMI coating.

  • Conductive contacts between the faces of the chassis are required to reduce the size of the openings along the chassis seams (the faces of the chassis should make continuous electrical contact).

  • Avoid non-conductive coating/paint on screws that are used to secure the motherboard to the chassis or used between chassis faces and expose solder mask on the PCB for the screws to make contact to the PCB ground layers.

  • Large metal parts of the system should be connected to chassis ground at more than one point. Examples of large metal parts include the PCB ground layers, chassis, metal frame of the display, metal casing of the camera modules, FPC cables, etc. Conductive gaskets or screws may be used to tie large metal structures together at multiple contact points.

  • The thermal solution (heat pipe, cold plate) should be grounded to eliminate or reduce any resonance effects that could couple noise in the vicinity of the thermal solution.

  • Refer to Intel White Paper #602554 for further guidelines on the EMI coating thickness and selection criteria, conductive contact between chassis faces and thermal solution grounding.

  • The figures below illustrate the guidance for chassis design considerations:

EMI Coating on Chassis Covers and Sidewalls
Faces of the Chassis should make Continuous Electrical Contact
Thermal Solution Grounding

Type A Connector Selection

  • To minimize RFI, select a type A receptacle shell that has a backside shield with multiple ground contact points to the PCB ground layers.

  • Ensure that the mechanical latches form a ground contact with the plug shell when inserted.

  • Apertures/openings in the receptacle shell should be minimized.

  • The receptacle connectors should be connected to metal chassis or enclosures through grounding fingers, screws, or conductive gaskets

Type C Connector Selection

  • The receptacle shell should have multiple connection points to the PCB ground layers.

  • Apertures in the receptacle should be minimized. If apertures are unavoidable, a maximum aperture size of 1.5 mm is recommended.

  • The receptacle connectors should be connected to metal chassis or enclosures through grounding fingers, screws, or conductive gaskets.

  • The mid-plate in the connector receptacle should be directly connected to system PCB ground layers.

  • Select a connector where the RFI pad in the receptacle has multiple grounding contacts to the receptacle shell.

The following figures illustrate the recommendations for USB Type C connector selection and for further details, refer to the USB Type C Cable and Connector Specification (https://www.usb.org/cable_connector)

Type-C Connector Selection
Conductive Gaskets to Ground IO Connectors to Chassis

Cable Routing and Shielding, Ground Cables to Chassis

Electromagnetic noise can radiate from internal cables carrying high-speed signals causing RF interference or cables can couple noise to sensitive circuits or nets on the PCB and cause RF immunity issues. Internal cables should be well shielded to reduce the noise radiation from it.

The following are key considerations while selecting and designing with internal cables (FPC/FFC):

  • The internal cable should be shielded with either full ground layers on top and bottom, or by using an EMI shielding film (silk screening with silver/copper ink, aluminum/copper film lamination).

  • For the shield to be effective, the shield layer should not be floating as a floating shield does not provide a return current path and may even make the noise radiation worse. To improve the ground contact of the shield, a direct PCB ground or chassis ground connection of the shield is recommended. Multiple grounding points may be needed for long FPCs (typically every 50mm)

  • The routing of the internal cables is also critical to reducing the amount of noise that can couple to the sensitive circuits. For further guidelines on cable routing, refer to Intel White Paper #602554.

  • The figures below illustrate the guidance for internal cable shielding and grounding

Internal Cable Design Criteria for EMI
Direct PCB or Chassis Ground Connection of the Cable Shield

Minimize ESD Chassis Entry Points

It is recommended to design the chassis/system industrial design to minimize ESD entry and thereby improve the system level ESD protection. Following are two examples of ESD entry points and mitigation methods:

  • Example 1: Speaker openings - In systems with metal mesh for the speaker openings, the ESD energy can be diverted to the system ground by connecting the metal mesh to system ground. This will minimize the ESD entry through the speaker lines into the PCB.

  • Example 2: SIM/SD trays - SIM/SD cards are very sensitive to ESD. Avoid any air gaps around the tray that otherwise can lead to ESD entry. Divert ESD into system ground by connecting the metal tray of the SIM/SD to the chassis ground or PCB ground layers.

Minimize ESD Entry Points in the Chassis

Antenna Barricade Technology

The chassis design may not be effective enough at higher frequency bands (6 GHz bands). Noise leakage observed in the seams, slots and between metal-to-metal bonding. Antenna barricade, metal enclosure around antenna, is an effective solution to mitigate RFI noise at platform level by physically and electromagnetically isolating the antenna from potential sources of interference. Experimental data shows ~10 dB noise reduction with antenna barricade. To avoid any opening/leakage EMI gasket material between barricade and chassis can be applied at multiple locations. However, antenna barricade needs to be planned upfront as it is part of chassis design.

Intel has developed a license technology on antenna barricade technology and design. Contact Intel for more information.

Example of Antenna Barricade in Mobile Design

EMC ESD Considerations

ESD Sensitive Net Mitigation

The following net categories may be sensitive to ESD:

  • Processor-Hot or PCH-Hot: *FORCEPR#*, *PCHHOT*

  • Reset: *RESET*, *RST*, *RSTB*, *DRAM_RESET*

  • Power-Ok, Power-Good: *PWROK*, *PWRGD*

  • Crystal: XTAL_IN, XTAL_OUT, RTC

System-level ESD issues may be mitigated by one of the following:

  • Routing sensitive nets as stripline.

  • Adding placeholder for decoupling capacitors on the sensitive nets to reduce the ESD level injected into the victim ICs (excluding crystal oscillator). The value of decoupling capacitor varies on different nets and systems. The recommended value is 1-100 nF.

For crystal oscillator, follow the guidelines from “XTAL Topology Guideline” (PCH/IOs chapter), “RTC (Real Time Clock) Topology” (PCH/IOs chapter) and “XTAL Ground Ring Requirement” (Electromagnetic Compatibility Chapter).

ESD Sensitive Net Mitigation

System Configuration

PCB Type: Type-3

PCB Layer Count: 10

PCB Thickness: 0.9mm

PCB Assembly: Double Sided

VCCGT

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design solid planes for a continuous current flow path from VR output to BGA. Please see reference image as an example of feasible placement. VCCGT_T3_1
2Adjacent solid ground to power planes for good return path.
3Sense pins routed as differential pair to VR. Avoid routing adjacent to noisy power plane and have adjacent solid ground plane for good return path.
VCCGT_T3_1
Notes
Note
1. Smaller capacitors should be placed closest to the package. For example: Package -> 0201 -> 0402 ->0603 ->Bulk -> VR.
2. For bottom layer capacitor placement, place 0201, 0402, 0603 capacitors directly under the package and cannot be placed at the edge.
3. Capacitor recommendation based on VR solution with 150 kHz VR bandwidth or 600 kHz switching frequency, assuming BW=1/4 of Fsw.
4. Align capacitor pads along current flow path from VR to package. Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitors pads.
5. Use MLCC components with 6.3 V voltage rating.
6. Please refer to acoustic noise mitigation technical advisory document #575216 for more details.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design

Secondary side02011 uF30VCCGT_T3_3
Secondary side040210 uF73VCCGT_T3_3
Secondary side060322 uF2VCCGT_T3_3
Secondary side7343220 uF7Recommended capacitor ESR = 4.5 mOhm with 2V voltage rating.VCCGT_T3_3
Secondary side0201Placeholder7VCCGT_T3_3

VCCPRIM_VNNAON

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design at least two solid and wide power planes as continuous current path from VR output all the way to BGAs. Advise to use 30um copper thickness layer for these two main routing layers. Ensure solid ground reference plane in nearby layers. Connect BGA pins when possibleVCCPRIM_VNNAON_1, VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
2The VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR rail require very clean supply, isolated from VCCPRIM_VNNAON in package and advise merge back to VCCPRIM_VNNAON only on board secondary side through an LC filter. VCCPRIM_VNNAON has two power pins CM16 and CM18.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses differential sensing BP14 (SENSE_VCCPRIM_VNNAON) and BP12(SENSE_VSS_VCCPRIM_VNNAON).
Maximum Rpath from VRM output inductor location to VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA groups is 3.85mOhm.
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
Notes
Note
Bulk caps and extra MLCC caps added to meet PD requirements to keep voltage below limit at sense point.
Place smaller capacitors closer to the package (i.e. placement from package to VR: 0402 → 0603 → 0805 →bulk capacitors). Align capacitors pads along current flow path from VR to package.
Make sure decoupling capacitors have power/ground via pairs connected as close as possible to the capacitor pads. Minimize the distance between these power/ground vias as much as possible.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary Side7343330uF1Place near VRM. ESR = 4.5 mΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
Primary/Secondary Side060322uF12Place near VRMVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4, VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary side060347uF3Place 3 x 0603 47uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA region. One of the cap place need to place in CPU die area.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side060322uF5Place 5 x 0603 22uF with distance <10mm from Package edge. VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side040210uF4Place 4 x 0402 10uF caps under VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGA region.VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side060322uF1Capacitor of LC filterVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Secondary Side0402/06031 uH_120mΩ DCR1Inductor of LC filter. Electrical requirement of the inductor: rated current > 200mA, DCR < 0.12ΩVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1"To meet Rpath of <2.5mΩ from VRM to pkg sense point, VCCPRIM_VNNAON plane is routed on at least three 30um-thick copper layers from VRM output to processor BGA with the following conditions : ► When routing on the top or bottom layer, keep plane width at least 15mm at VRM region & not lesser than 9mm upon approaching BGA region ► When routing on buildup layers (minimum 2 layers), keep plane width at least 17mm at VRM region & not lesser than 12mm upon approaching BGA region " VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
2Short all VCCPRIM_VNNAON BGAs with plane on at least of two 30um-thick copper layersVCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
3VCCPRIM_VNNAON VRM uses pseudo differential sensing to compensate for voltage drops along the power delivery path. The PWR & GND sense lines are connected to L53 & K53 BGAs respectivelyVCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
4Short both VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs (W53 & W51) with planeVCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
5Merge both VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR & VCCPRIM_VNNAON power planes using 1 x 0603 1uH (120mΩ max DCR) inductor & 1 x 0603 22uF cap to form an LC-filter with the following conditions : ► Place the LC-filter <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs ► Ensure the merging point for both VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR planes are <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs Note : Refer diagram for design implementation guidanceVCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_1
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_2
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_3
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_4
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_5
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements
Heighten capacitor effectiveness by placing them from VRM output to package in the following order : 0402 → 0603 → 0805 → Bulk
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads
When placing capacitors, align their pads to the current path flowing from VR to package
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor provided the caps meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNoteReference Design
Primary/Secondary side7343470 uF111Place bulk cap near to VRM output VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Primary/Secondary7343220 uF111Place bulk cap near to VRM output VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Primary060347 uF666Place caps near to VRM output VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary060347 uF666Place caps near to VRM output VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary060347 uF666Place caps at the center between VRM output and BGA VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7
Secondary060347 uF666Place 6 x 0603 47uF caps <10mm from package edge. Make sure PWR-GND PTH pair is placed very close to cap terminalsVCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary040222 uF444Place 4 x 0402 22uF caps underneath BGA or <1mm from package edge. Make sure PWR-GND PTH pair is placed very close to cap terminals VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary060322 uF111Pair 1 x 0603 22uF VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR cap with 1 x 0603 1uH (120mΩ max DCR) inductor <1mm from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs to form an LC-filter VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
Secondary06031 uH_120mΩ111"Merge both VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR & VCCPRIM_VNNAON power planes using 1 x 0603 1uH (120mΩ max DCR) inductor & 1 x 0603 22uF cap to form an LC-filter with the following conditions : ► Place the LC-filter <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs ► Ensure the merging point for both VCCPRIM_VNNAON & VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR planes are <1mm distance from or underneath VCCPRIM_VNNAON_FLTR BGAs " VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_6
VCCPRIM_VNNAON_7

VCCPRIM_IO

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Design at least one solid power planes from pin field to VRM, if possible, place two planes in parallel. Place the immediate adjacent layers as vss plane. Connect BGA pins when possible.VCCPRIM_IO_1
2VCCPRIM_IO requires an LC filter for the CLKs, VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR has two pins CM14/CP14 and merge back to VCCPRIM_IO on board through LC filter. VCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
3VCCPRIM_IO requires differential sense, use pin DF8/DF9VCCPRIM_IO_2
4Maximum Rpath from VRM location to VCCPRIM_IO BGA group is 5.53mOhmVCCPRIM_IO_1
VCCPRIM_IO_1
VCCPRIM_IO_2
Notes
Note
Additional capacitors may be required for meeting other PD requirements, please refer to recommendations from VR vendors.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Secondary side02011uF4Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGAVCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side040210uF3Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGAVCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side060322uF3Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO BGAVCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side080547uF4Could place after BO or near VRMVCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Primary/Secondary side7343330uFPlace near VRMVCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side06031uH1Inductor of LC filter. The following requirements for the inductor must be met: - DCR: 350mOhm VCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side0402/060322uF1Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail for LC filtering purposeVCCPRIM_IO_3, VCCPRIM_IO_4
Secondary side02011uF1Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR BGA
VCCPRIM_IO_3
VCCPRIM_IO_4

Settings (Internal)

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route VCCPRIM_IO power plane from VR output inductor to the BGA on the bottom layer (L10).VCCPRIM_IO_1
2VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR should be merged with VCCPRIM_IO after the LC filter on the bottom layer (L10).VCCPRIM_IO_1
VCCPRIM_IO_1
Notes
Note
Place VRM bulk cap or additional MLCC caps to keep sense voltage below threshold limit & to fulfill PD requirements.
Improve capacitor effectiveness by placing them from package to VRM in the following order : 0402, 0603, 0805, Bulk.
Establish robust return path for decoupling capacitor by minimizing the distance between power & ground via pairs as well as placing the via pairs as close as possible to the capacitor pads.
Align capacitor pads to the current path flowing from VR to package.
Customers can choose capacitors of any form factor if the capacitors meet the recommended parasitic capacitance.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNote
Primary/Secondary side080547uF444Place near VRM
Secondayr side060322uF333PI caps near BGAs
Secondary side040210uF333PI caps near BGAs
Secondary side02011uF444PI caps near BGAs
Secondary side (inductor)06031uH111Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail with ESR = 350mO
Secondary040222uH111Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR rail for LC filtering purpose
Secondary02011uF111Place right below the VCCPRIM_IO_FLTR BGAs.

VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Route the VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC, VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA and VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB on 2 layers, with immediate ground reference. VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA should be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC after LC filter on Primary Layer. VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRB can be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC on Layer 4.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_1
VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_1
Notes
Note
Power and ground via pairs should be placed close to capacitor pads to provide proper vertical connections when placing capacitor on the secondary side.

Primary side0603 / 08051uH1Inductor component of the LC filter from VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC rail to VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA rail. It must meet electrical requirements: max DCR < 100mOhm and rated current >200 mA.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_3
Primary side060322uF2Decoupling capacitor placed on VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_FLTRA rail for LC filtering purpose.VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_2, VCCPRIM_1P8_PROC_3

System Configuration

PCB Type: Type-3

PCB Layer Count: 10

PCB Thickness: 0.9mm

PCB Assembly: Double Sided

VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8 can be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8_PCH after LC filter. VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1, VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_2
2Recommended minimum VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8 power plane width of 1 mm on Breakout pins region and more than 2mm after PKG edge, with immediate GND reference. Wherever possible, it is recommended to provide GND trace shielding along VCCAHSIOPLLL_1P8 power plane to further minimize coupling noise from adjacent power/ signals.VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1
3Merge pin V17 and pin T14 together on Layer 1.VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1
VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1

Primary side04020 Ohm / 100 mOhm1This Resistor_1 must be placed in series with Capacitor_1 Default = 0 Ohm; If inductor is stuffed = 100 mOhmVCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1, VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_2
Primary side04022.2uF1Place Capacitor_2 <10 mm from package edge, with immediate GND reference.VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1, VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_2
Primary side060310 uF1Place Capacitor_1 <10 mm from package edge, with immediate GND reference.VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1, VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_2
Primary side0603 / 0805Placeholder1Inductor by default is a placeholder. If inductor not stuffed, place a 0 Ohm resistor as default. If inductor stuffed, inductor must meet the following requirements: Rated at least 2000 mA Max DCR = 10 mOhm Minimum inductance = 250 nHVCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_1, VCCAHSIOPLL_1P8_2

VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1All 3 pins, i.e. Y15, Y17, V15 can be shorted together at surface layer, and share common power rail, called VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1
2Recommended minimum VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8 power plane width of 2 mm, with immediate GND reference. Wherever possible, it is recommended to provide GND shielding along VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8 power plane to further minimize coupling noise from adjacent power rail/ signals.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1
3VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8 can be merged with VCCPRIM_1P8_PCH after LC filter.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1, VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_2
VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1

Primary side0603 / 08052.2uH1If inductor is not stuffed, place a 0 Ohm resistor. If inductor is stuffed, the following requirements must be met: - Rated at least 150 mA . - Minimum inductance = 2.2 uH.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1, VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_2

1All 3 pins, i.e. Y15, Y17, V15 can be shorted together at surface layer, and share common power rail, called VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1

Primary side080547 uF111Place Capacitor_1 <10 mm from package edge, with immediate GND reference. Recommended to use 0805 FF to evaluate the worst-case capacitor FF; in case there is no space, change it to 0603VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_1, VCCA_XTAL_PLL_1P8_2

VCCA_PLL_1P25

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Recommended minimum VCCA_PLL_1P25 power plane width of 2 mm, with immediate GND reference. Wherever possible, widen the plane width to minimize DC drop.VCCA_PLL_1P25_1
2Merge with VCCPRIM_1P25 and VCCPRIM_1P05_1P25 after BO; keep the power rail isolated from VCCPRIM_1P05_1P25 along 12.35mm from the BO.VCCA_PLL_1P25_2
3Merge with VCCPRIM_1P25 and VCCPRIM_1P05_1P25 after BO; keep the power rail isolated from VCCPRIM_1P25 along 4.6mm from the BO.VCCA_PLL_1P25_2
VCCA_PLL_1P25_1
VCCA_PLL_1P25_2
Notes
Note
Merge with VCCPRIM_1P25 & VCCPRIM_1P05_1P25 after BO.
Component Placement
N/A

Settings (Internal)

Design Note
Please refer to notes in the external section.
Notes
Note
Merge with VCCPRIM_1p25 and VCCPRIM_1p05_1p25 after BO.
Component PlacementForm FactorValueSoldered DownISC SocketPPV SocketNoteReference Design
Primary side04021uF111Place Cap_1 <5 mm from the package edge. It can be placed either at primary or secondary side. However, when placed at secondary side, VCC and VSS vias need to be adjacent to each other.VCC_PLL_1p25_3
VCC_PLL_1P25_3

VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1All 4 pins should be shorted together at Layer 1 and 2, and share common power rail, called VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_1
2Recommended minimum VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85 power plane width of 1.65 mm, with immediate GND reference. Wherever possible, it is recommended to provide GND shielding along VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85 power plane to further minimize coupling noise from adjacent power rail/ signals.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_2
3VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85 can be merged with VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85 after LC filter.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_3
VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_1
VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_2
VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_3
Component PlacementForm FactorValueQuantityNoteReference Design
Primary side060347 uF1Place Capacitor_1 <9 mm from package edge, with immediate GND reference.VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_3
Primary side0603 / 0805Placeholder1If inductor is not stuffed, place a 120mΩ resistor. If inductor stuffed, the following requirements must be met: - Rated at least 310 mA. - Minimum inductance = 2.2 uH. -RDC = 120 mΩVCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85_3

VCCPGPPA

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1VCCPGPPA can be merged directly to either VCCPRIM_3P3 or VCCPRIM_1P8_PCH power plane depending on the operating voltage. Require immediate ground reference for VCCPGPPA power plane.VCCPGPPA_1
2This power plane require 30um copper thickness. If operating at 1.8 V, extend VCCPGPPA plane to merge with VCCPRIM_1P8_PCH plane. VCCPGPPA_1
3This power plane require 30um copper thickness. If operating at 3.3 V, extend VCCPGPPA plane to merge with VCCPRIM_3P3 plane.VCCPGPPA_1
VCCPGPPA_1
Component PlacementForm FactorValue
N/A

3This power plane requires 30um copper thickness. If operating at 3.3 V, extend VCCPGPPA plane to merge with VCCPRIM_3P3 plane.VCCPGPPA_1

VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85

Settings

IndexDesign NoteReference Design
1Short all VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85 pins on Layer 1 to VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85 power rail. Recommended to place VCC & VSS Vias adjacent to each others.VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85_1
2Recommended VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85 minimum power plane width of 1.18 mm, with immediate GND reference.VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85_2
3Place 0.85 V voltage regulator feedback sense point (i.e. differential pair) close to VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85 BGAs.VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85_2
4Power entry for VCCA_XTAL_PLL_0P85 is through VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85 & is sensitive. Isolation recommendation as in reference design.VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85_3
5High level platform merging scheme.VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85_4
VCCPRIM_CORE_0P85_1

RCOMP

RCOMP Connection Diagram
Example_RCOMP_with_GND_shield
RCOMP General Guidelines
Detail
Trace width 75um with min trace spacing 100um.
Max total length on board = 9 mm. Max number of vias 1.
GND shield to any high speed IO with VSS trace/ strip. This is not required if the adjacent signal is another RCOMP signal. PTH vias are required to be punched from this GND shield to the referenced GND plane.
GND reference required. Noisy or switching references should be avoided.
Board external resistor size=0201(recommended).
Strongly recommended to follow breakout board placement.
RCOMP Configuration
InterfaceSignal NameBoard RTerm (Ohm)Max Board DC resistance (Ohm)Tolerance (+/-)%Connection on other SideMax Board Parasitic Capacitance (pF)Resistor StuffingRouting Guide
CNViSTEP_REXT (PCH)2000.11GND1.5Mandatoryrefer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
DisplayDMI_RCOMP (PCH)2000.11GND1.5Mandatoryrefer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
PCIePCIE_RCOMP2 (PCH)2000.11GND1.5Mandatoryrefer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.

RCOMP (Internal)

RCOMP Connection Diagram
Example_RCOMP_with_GND_shield
RCOMP_with_floating
RCOMP General Guidelines
Detail
Trace width 75um with min trace spacing 100um.
Max total length on board = 9 mm. Max number of vias 1.
GND shield to any high speed IO with VSS trace/ strip. This is not required if the adjacent signal is another RCOMP signal. PTH vias are required to be punched from this GND shield to the referenced GND plane.
GND reference required. Noisy or switching references should be avoided.
Board external resistor size=0201(recommended).
Strongly recommended to follow breakout board placement.
RCOMP Configuration
InterfaceSignal NameBoard RTerm (Ohm)Max Board DC resistance (Ohm)Tolerance (+/-)%Connection on other SideMax Board Parasitic Capacitance (pF)Resistor StuffingRouting Guide
CNViSTEP_REXT (PCH)2000.11GND1.5Mandatorya) TIU/SV/DV testing need to apply external resistor 200 Ohm +/- "0.1"% tolerance. refer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
CNViCNV_RCOMP (CPU)2000.11GND1.5Mandatorya) TIU/SV/DV testing need to apply external resistor 200 Ohm +/- "0.1"% tolerance. refer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
DisplayDDI_RCOMP (CPU)1500.11GND1.5Mandatoryrefer to the RCOMP General Guidelines.
Type CPCD_TC_2_GRCOMP (CPU)00.10N/A1.5Floatinga) Leave it floating and no connect after PTH via refer to the RCOMP_with_floating picture and apply the RCOMP General Guidelines.
Type CPCD_TC_2_GRCOMPV (CPU)00.10N/A1.5Floatinga) Leave it floating and no connect after PTH via refer to the RCOMP_with_floating picture and apply the RCOMP General Guidelines.
